qas.question: What is the main principle of lectio brevior?

answers.text: scribes tended to add words, for clarification or out of habit

qas.question: What is the main principle of lectio difficilior?

answers.text: the tendency for harmonization—resolving apparent inconsistencies in the text.

qas.question: Is a lectio brevrio or lectio difficilior approach more akin to the original text?

answers.text: Applying this principle leads to taking the more difficult (unharmonized) reading as being more likely to be the original.

qas.question: What is the term for when words are deducted for clarification?
What is the term for when there are consistencies in the text?

context: Two common considerations have the Latin names <b5_0><b7_0>lectio brevior<b7_0/><b5_0/> (<a0_0>shorter reading<a0_0/>) and <b6_0>lectio difficilior<b6_0/> (<a1_0>more difficult reading<a1_0/>). The first is the general observation that <a2_0>scribes tended to add words, for clarification or out of habit<a2_0/>, more often than they removed them. The second, <b8_0>lectio difficilior<b8_0/> potior (the harder reading is stronger), recognizes <a3_0>the tendency for harmonization—resolving apparent inconsistencies in the text.<a3_0/> <a4_0>Applying this principle leads to taking the more difficult (unharmonized) reading as being more likely to be the original.<a4_0/> Such cases also include scribes simplifying and smoothing texts they did not fully understand.
